text: DELLA YOUNG, called as a witness herein, having been first duly sworn, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION
Could you please state and spell your first and last name for the record?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My name is Della Young, D-E-L-L-A, Y-O-U-N-G.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let the record reflect that this is the discovery deposition of Della Young taken pursuant to notice by agreement of the parties and witness and pursuant to all Illinois Rules of Civil Procedure, Illinois Supreme Court Rules, and local rules.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Good morning, Ms. Young.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Good morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever given a deposition before?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long ago?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: About three years ago.  Three, four years ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Only one deposition?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was that in a case where you were a party or were you a witness?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I was a witness.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What type of case was that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: It was a medical malpractice.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it in Cook County?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have to testify at trial?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You may remember from that experience, and I am sure your attorney went over with you about what to expect today.  I am just going to run through some of the standard ground rules today so that we are all on the same page. As you can see we have a court reporter here taking down everything that we say.  For that reason all your answers need to be out loud.  Feel free to shake your head, nod your head, shrug your shoulders, as long as you also give an out loud response.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Similarly, uh-huh and uh-uh look exactly the same in writing.  So if the court reporter, me, or your attorney says is that a yes or a no, it is not because we don't know what you mean.  We are just making sure the record is clear.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If at any point you need to take a break, need something to drink, use the restroom, speak to your attorney, perfectly fine.  Just let me know, so long as there is no question pending.  If any of my questions don't make sense to you or you would like me to rephrase them in some way, please let me know and I am happy to do that.  If you answer the question, I am going to assume that you understood it.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sometimes people think they know what they are answering and then we get a few questions down the road and realize we are talking about two separate things. So if you have any questions about what I am asking about, feel free to let me know.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your attorney may object to some of my questions.  I may object to some of his.  We don't have a judge here to rule on those objections.  So unless your attorney instructs you not to answer, and you choose to take that instruction, you need to answer that question. And then one last thing, in casual conversation I know we talk over each other a lot.  You probably will know where I am going with some of these questions, but for the sake of the court reporter wait until I am done with my question until you answer; and likewise, I will wait until you finish your answer before I ask the next question.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is your date of birth?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Happy recent birthday to you.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what are the last four digits of your social?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: What is your current address?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: 6402 South Long Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Long?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Long, L-O-N-G, and that's in Chicago 60638.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who do you live there with?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My husband and my son and my recent daughter-in-law.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is your husband's name?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Ronald Marciniak.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And spell that last name?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: M-A-R-C-I-N-I-A-K.  We have been together for 36 years.  We just decided to get married in April.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh wow, congratulations.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Thank you.  Even the judge was you are holding the record for me.  And everybody is why did you wait so long?  Well, I didn't know if I wanted to kick him to the curb or not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: 36 years convinced you it's worth sticking around.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: He was playing hard to get.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is your son's name?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Ronald Marciniak.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how old is your son?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Ronald is 29.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you said your daughter-in-law is with you as well?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is her name?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Lauren McGurn, M-C-G-U-R-N.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long have you all lived at the address on Long Avenue?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: 15 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And any plans to move in the near future?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I hope so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You are looking to move?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  Actually, we are going to Florida next month.  We usually go every year because we do a big family trip, but my husband wasn't doing too well, and so we decided to wait.  We are going in September and we are driving.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have a place down there?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  We are actually going to stay at Treasure Island, and we are going to bring our dog with us, hundred pound German Shepherd.  He is a police dog.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Long drive, though, right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Oh, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's see.  Do you have any other children other than Ronald?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What are your other children?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I have Heather.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How old is Heather?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Heather is 36.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And anyone else?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Walter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how old is Walter?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Walter is 28.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And any others?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Veronica, she is 27.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And any others?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Monica who is 26.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, my goodness.  They are so close in age.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Amanda is 25.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, my gosh.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Do we need to keep going?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have more?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Let's see.  Amanda.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Amanda is 25. BY THE WITNESS:
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Monica, Veronica, Amanda.  Who is next?  You put me on the spot.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many total children?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Oh wow.  And how old is your youngest?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Max is ten.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where does Max lives?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Max lives with his adoptive parents.  Max is ten years old.  He was born on Christmas Eve, emergency, of course.  I had a -- I can't think of the name -- with the blood.  I had to have an emergency C-section.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Because my blood pressure was, like, 200 over 70.  So I don't know what you called that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Preeclampsia?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, I had preeclampsia.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do all of your children live in Illinois?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you originally from Illinois?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you lived around the Chicago area since?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: All my life.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is your highest level of education?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: 9th grade.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where did you attend 9th grade?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Lourdes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's in Chicago, correct?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  It is now Hancock.  It is now called Hancock.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Since 9th grade have you completed any kind of certificate or degree programs of any type?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you currently employed?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When is the last time that you were employed?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Three years ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was that with the dental office?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Khouri Dental?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Dr. Khouri, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's, for the record, K-H-O-U-R-I?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you work for Dr. Khouri?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Eight years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was your position?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I was office manager and dental assistant.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where is Dr. Khouri's office located?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: 87th and Harlem.  7257 West 87th Street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And based on the records we received from your lawyer, it said that you stopped working there in around September of 2016; is that correct?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the circumstances that led to you stop working?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: When I originally had my accident, I went back, and I went from 40 hours to 30 hours because our office dealt with mentally and physically handicapped patients, and I couldn't handle my workload because of my accident.  So I was cut down to 30 hours and then cut down again to 12 hours, and then terminated.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To 12 hours?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yeah, it went down to 12 hours a week and then I was terminated.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that was in a span of about a month?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  That's --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Because your accident was in August.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: August, correct.  It was August 7th.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at some point in September you were let go?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  It was the week before Christmas.  It was the one week exactly before Christmas.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you request that your hours be reduced or did the office?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: The doctor because I couldn't move patients. I couldn't do anything.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What were your general job duties as the office manager at that location?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I arranged transportation for patients.  I made appointments.  I assisted the doctor.  I cleaned the office.  I sterilized all the instruments.  I took X-rays.  I did impressions for dentures.  I have done almost everything except pull a tooth.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many other staff members were working there?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: There was -- when I first started there was six of us, and then we went down to four, and then we went down to the four of us, it was me, the doctor, the doctor's -- and the doctor's sister.  So we went down to three.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the time of your accident at Wal-Mart was it down to three?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: It was four, yeah.  Me and the other three.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When your hours were reduced, do you know who was taking on those responsibilities?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Angie was terminated, and then it was the doctor, the doctor's sister, and I.  Actually, I got terminated, and then, you know, the doctor and her sister were always fighting so she has fired her a hundred times.  So I don't know what happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So Angie was another staff member?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was she terminated before or after your accident?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Before.  It was a year before.  She was an older lady, you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Then since being terminated from Dr. Khouri's office, have you sought out employment elsewhere?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, several times.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you started working anywhere else?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you looking for a similar type job?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I wish I could, but I don't have no degree.  I was trained hands on which was another blessing for me and nowadays you have to have a degree.  So to lose that job was like, whew.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Before the accident at Wal-Mart you said you were working 40 hours a week?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was your rate of pay?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: When I started out, I started at $8 an hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: And when I left I was at 14.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you making $14 an hour at the time of your accident at Wal-Mart?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever filed a workers' comp. claim?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever filed for bankruptcy?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever filed or been a party to any other personal injury claim?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was that medical malpractice you gave a deposition for related to your work with Dr. Khouri?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Well, I was the assistant that did the procedure on the patient so I had to testify to what actually happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But you became involved through your job?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have a primary care physician?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is his or her name?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Dr. Danica Milenkovich and I cannot spell that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think I have it.  M-I-L-E-N-K-O-V-I-C-H.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Sounds correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long have you been a patient of hers?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My husband and I have both been a patient of hers I want to say for 11 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And she is through Mercy Medical Center?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Prior to your accident at Wal-Mart, so just talking all the times before then, and then we will talk about medical after in a little bit.  But before your fall at Wal-Mart, had you ever injured either of your knees?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever sought any kind of treatment for either knee?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever had any kind of chronic pain or anything like that in your knees?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Before your fall at Wal-Mart had you ever injured either shoulder?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Same questions, have you ever sought treatment for either shoulder?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you ever seen an orthopedic surgeon before you fell at Wal-Mart?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  Once when I was 13.  I broke my arm. And then probably about 13 years ago I broke the same arm in the same place.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the name of the doctor you saw?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what hospital system he was in?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: MacNeal.  I think it was MacNeal because I walked around for three months with a broken arm thinking it will get better, but when I had to start moving it manually, I knew something was wrong.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's your right arm?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  It was my forearm.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have to have any surgery for that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  Actually, it broke in the exact same place that I broke it the first time, and it started to heal the same way.  So they just put it in a cast.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long were you in a cast?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Probably about six weeks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have to go to physical therapy at all?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So I want to turn to the day of your fall at Wal-Mart, and as you stated before, that was August 7, 2016, right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So if I refer to the fall or the accident, that's the date I am talking about, okay?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this was the Bedford Park store; is that right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you ever been to the Bedford Park store before?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Every other Sunday of the month.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that where you do your typical shopping?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I used to, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How far is that store from where you were living at the time?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Probably two miles, three miles.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: On the day of the your fall, were you coming from your house to go there?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you drive?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  My husband drove.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone else go with you?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  It was just us.  Our Sunday out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there anything in particular that you were going there to get?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, our normal things.  We get dog food, cat food, cat litter, soda, shampoo, conditioner. Everything that you would need on a weekly basis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember about what time of day you went to the store?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: It was in the afternoon.  I think it was about 2.  Maybe, between 12 and 2.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What had you done earlier that day, if you remember?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Woke up.  Did my morning thing.  Let my dogs out.  We went for breakfast, like we do every Sunday. We went to church and then we went to Wal-Mart.  Well, I stopped home, changed my clothes, and then we went to Wal-Mart.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you arrived at the store, were you in pain in any area of your body?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  I was happy to go shopping.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you on any medications that day?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the 24 hours before going to the store had you had any alcohol or any other kind of medication?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I don't drink, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what kind of shoes you were wearing?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I had Sketchers on.  That's all I wear because I wear them for work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sketchers sneakers?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you still have those?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, I do.  That's all I buy is Sketchers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Brand loyalty there.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  I buy Bob's, two pair at a time.  The whole family shops there.  So I was able to go and get a brand new pair of gym shoes just on my Sketcher points, $70.00.  So it was kind of cool.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It doesn't look like you are wearing glasses today.  Do you normally wear glasses or contacts?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  Well, I wear glasses for reading and I am going to have an eye exam because I do think I need them now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But in 2016 you didn't have to wear them for driving or anything?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you get to the store with your husband sometime between 12 and 2.  Can you describe for me once you arrived at the store what you did?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: We just walked through and did our shopping, picked up our things here and there.  And then we checked out, and I got outside and I went, I forgot the dog food and that's what I came for. So I was, like, oh, my God.  So I walked through, and I walked through the self-checkout, and the next thing I knew I was on the floor.  And I had two people pick me up. And I was, like, you know, what happened?  And then I was sticky like a jam kind of slimy, wet, sticky all over me.  And the two people that had picked me up --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Della, just listen to her question and answer her question.  She is going to ask you --
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: We are going to break it down.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: She will break all that stuff down. Just listen to her question and answer the question. BY THE WITNESS:
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: I just fell.  I slipped and down I went.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you and your husband go to the store and you did all of your shopping.  You said you checked out. Did you check out at the self registers or did you check out at the regular registers?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I checked out at the regular registers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And you left the store and went to your car?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  We walked outside and I looked at the cart and realized that I had forgot the dog food which was the main reason I went there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your husband go back inside with you or did you go back in alone?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No, no.  I went back in alone and he loaded the car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where in the store, since it sounds like you are pretty familiar with this location, is the dog food located?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: All the way in the back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And on that day do you remember what entrance you went in and out of?  Was it the main entrance or near the pharmacy?  Usually there is two entrances?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: It was near the -- I would say near the, like, the grocery side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you seen the video of your fall?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I just seen it today.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you recognize yourself on it?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you see yourself fall on that video?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just for --
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: It looked more fun than it actually was.  It was, like, I posed or something.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, no, that's okay.  So you -- did you get all the way outside the store before you realized that you forgot the dog food or were you in that vestibule area?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I walked out the doors and we were right in front of the store and I looked at my husband and said I forgot the dog food.  And I said, okay.  I am going to go back in.  He said he was going to load the car.  I walked in and I walked through and I went down.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So when you reentered the store you walked by the self-checkout area, correct.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  I walked through it.  I shouldn't have, but I did.  It was a shortcut.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What caused you to fall?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: From my understanding some fruity substance on the floor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, when you say from my understanding, did you see the fruit on the floor?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see it before you fell?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You saw it after you fell?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know what fruit was on the floor?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Supposedly it was grapes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did someone tell you they were grapes?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who told you that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Two other people that were in line.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Customers?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what those customers looked like at all?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: They were African-American ladies, and there was two woman and one gentleman.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did they say to you?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: After I went down, they were picking me up from the back, and they were, like, oh, my God, she fell on those grapes.  And then I was, like, I looked and it was just all over me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All over you where?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: All over my leg; all over my hands.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What color grapes were they?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I think they were the grape ones, the purple colored ones because the guts were purple.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And can you describe for me what they looked like on the ground when you first saw them?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: They were trampled.  They obviously had been there because they were trampled when I fell.  Because it wasn't, like, they were whole.  It was, like, they were on the ground, and went like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know if it was your foot that caused them to be smashed or if they were smashed before?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: They were smashed before.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how do you know that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Because they weren't freshly smashed.  They were kind of sticky, like, they had been there and they had been stepped in a couple of times.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone tell you what those grapes looked like before you fell?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you didn't see the grapes before you fell, right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were there any employees nearby?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  There was a self-checkout helper.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Female or male?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Female.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did she come over after you fell?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After you fell did any employees come over to you?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you come to speak to any employees after you fell?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how did that happen?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: After I had fallen, I called my husband because I couldn't move, and I asked him -- I told him I fell.  And he said you are kidding me.  And he came in and picked me up off the floor. He walked me over to the Subway which had two security guards; told me that I had fallen.  They had then notified the store manager. She came over; said what happened?  I told her I fell.  She asked what hurt.  I said my knee because the immediate pain I felt, it felt like under my kneecap was bleeding.  That's how painful it was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And which knee?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My left knee.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: And then she came and brought me some ice packs and then she -- I am not sure if I signed anything, but then that was it.  She walked away and we were done.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know what her name was, that manager that you spoke to?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: You know what, it was an unusual name.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's okay if you don't remember.  Do you remember what she looked like?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: She was Hispanic, tall, thin, mid-length hair.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than her, did you speak to any other employees in the store?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they ask you if you needed an ambulance?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you request an ambulance?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  By this time I was just, like, a nervous wreck?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Between the time you fell and the time that you eventually left the store, how much time passed?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Probably about 20 minutes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know how the grapes came to be on the floor?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see anybody drop any grapes before you fell?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anybody tell you how those grapes got to be on the floor?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how long they were on the floor before the fall?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know whether any Wal-Mart employees knew about those grapes before you fell?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You described for me feeling some knee pain. Can you describe how your body landed when you fell, if you remember?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: It was kind of funny.  It was kind of like one of those, oops, I meant to do that.  When it happened, I came down on my left knee, bounced back on my right arm, and then landed on my ass.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you hit your head at all?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  It was just mostly the knee and the shoulder that took the brunt of it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you fell, were you holding anything in your hand?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Just my purse.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was anything blocking your view of the floor when you were walking through that self-checkout area?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: It was pretty crowded.  There was some people in line.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you able to see where you were going though?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you distracted by anything?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  I was focused on getting the dog food.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

text: Um-hum.

text: Yes.  I'm sorry.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Right.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Walking by self-checkout.  There were grapes on the floor I did not see and then fell.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Lupe.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: The pink purse, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Right over here (pointing).
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you are pointing to what, the entrance to the self-checkout?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  This is the entrance because this is where I came in.  I came in this way, and then as I was walking, that's where I fell.  Because these people right here, they are the ones that picked me up and told me about the grapes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So I am just going to walk you through that so when we are reading this back later we know what we are talking about. So you walked through this area towards this entrance to the self-checkout where we see some merchandise on either side?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you pointed to these people at that first self-checkout register on the right-hand side?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And they are the customers that helped you up?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I didn't speak with them.  I was told not to speak with them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I want to show you what we have as a transcription of an interview from December 7, 2016, that we have marked as Exhibit 2.  And feel free to take a minute and look through that.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: (Witness looking through document.)
Does looking at this refresh your memory?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  This is when I had talked to Mark.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So I want you to just kind of look through this, feel free to flip through it, and let me know if everything in here looks correct and accurate to the best of your memory.

text: Okay.

text: (Witness looking through document.)
Okay.  You had an opportunity to flip through this?

text: Yes.

text: Yes.

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: That was Lupe.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Before.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

text: No.

text: They only showed up until when I fell.  That was it.

text: Off the record.

text: (Discussion off the record.)
We can go back on the record.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: So just to confirm, your memory of the incident is that while you were in the Subway area you could see the self-checkout area where you fell and you did you not see any employees cleaning up the area?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No, because the way I was positioned, the self-checkout is here, and they had me sitting this way, and they had my knee up with the ice pack and I was looking at the self-checkout.  I was waiting to see if anyone was going to clean it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So for the purposes of the record, the self-checkout area was on your left-hand side and you could look over and see it?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you were looking over to see whether it was going to be cleaned up?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I was just looking because that's the way they had me positioned.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When is the first time that you sought medical care for your injuries after your fall.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: On the 9th.

text: And where did you go?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I went to the -- it is Harlem Medical.  It is two doors away from where I worked.  Because that happened on a Sunday.  Monday morning I did not go to work because I couldn't walk. And then Tuesday I limped into work.  I tried to work.  I went to see the doctor.  The doctor sent me for an MRI, and then that's when everything started happening.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So on Tuesday you tried to go into work.  You were experiencing pain so you went to Harlem Medical at that point?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: On Wednesday which was the 9th.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, okay.  What doctor sent you for an MRI?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Dr. Rashan.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you seen Dr. Rashan before?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know what kind of doctor Dr. Rashan is?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: He is just a general M.D.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you tell him about your fall at Wal-Mart?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What parts of your body were you experiencing pain in when you went to see Dr. Rashan?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My knee and my shoulder.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that is your right knee?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My left knee and my right shoulder, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And right shoulder.  Other than your left knee and right shoulder, did you injure any other parts of your body during your fall?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My butt was sore.

text: Anything else?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. HASKELL

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I'm really not sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: If I didn't go that day, I think I went the next day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At some point you went to see an orthopedic surgeon named Dr. Silver; is that right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Um-hum.

text: No.  I see Dr. Rashan, and then I went to see Dr. Silver.

text: Did Dr. Rashan refer you to Dr. Silver?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And we received some of your medical records from your attorney, and those medical records show that you went to Dr. Silver on August 31st.  Does that sound right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.

text: Did you tell him about your fall at Wal-Mart?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did he recommend?  And, again, I know you are not a physician so I don't expect you to know all the terms.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: He recommended to have a scope done on my knee and rotator cuff repair.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did he prescribe you any pain medication?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, he did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what that was?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: He gave me Tramadol and then the Tramadol, I had a bad reaction to it.  So he gave me the Hydrocodone, five milligrams, and that was it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often did you have to take the Hydrocodone?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Before the surgery three to four times a day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: He gave you an injection for your shoulder, correct?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  That was cortisone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have just one injection?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: He did the injection, and it lasted probably about two months, and then I seen another orthopedic surgeon, Brian Amerson, and he just repeated everything that Dr. Silver did, but when he gave me the second injection in my shoulder, if felt like my arm was going to blow up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were in more pain after the injection?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was Dr. Brian Amerson at the same practice as Dr. Silver?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  Dr. Silver stopped taking my -- he didn't take my insurance so I had to find an orthopedic surgeon that did and that was Dr. Amerson?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  The records show that you kept seeing Dr. Silver through about June of 2017.  Does that sound about right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yeah.  He was a wonderful doctor.

text: Dr. Silver?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

text: Yes.

text: Athletic.

text: Yeah.

text: Okay.

text: Yes.  Isn't that Hydrocodone?

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  I mean, some days it was two to three times.  Some days it was just one.  It depended.

speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: February 1st, correct.

text: Yes.  He is amazing.

So when I heard that I was excited and I went to see Dr. Miller.  And he did another MRI and he did X-rays and he scheduled me for surgery exactly a month later.

text: So your primary doc had referred you to him?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

text: And you had that shoulder surgery at Mercy?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, in the outpatient center.

text: Correct.

Off the record.

text: (Brief interruption.)
We can go back on the record.

text: Okay.  After your right shoulder surgery with Dr. Miller, you continued to follow up with him; is that right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes, until he advised me that he was no longer accepting my insurance and that he was leaving Mercy Hospital.

text: When did that happen?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Right after I started seeing him.  Right after my surgery.  Like, I seen him, like, three times after my surgery, and he just recommended that I go to physical therapy, which I did.  I did it at Mercy.  I did it at one of Mercy's little clinics.  Then I went to UIC.  I seen another orthopedic surgeon that also recommended me for therapy, and now I am registered to do therapy at Mercy Medical on 55th and Pulaski.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Let's back up a little bit and go through that. So you had a few visits with Dr. Miller after your shoulder surgery, right?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

text: Oh, yeah.

text: No.  Actually, when I did go see him, and after that visit, and he asked me to take my sling off and I did.  And he showed me -- he asked me to move my arm, and I did.  That's the only time I took the sling off.

text: At his office?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.

text: Um --

text: Yes.

text: Um-hum.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Amerson.

text: Dr. Miller.

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Was that at Mercy?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  That was at UIC.  They were trying to do different -- because I have other issues besides this for physical therapy.  They were trying to get all the dates together.  They just had a lack of communication. So that's when I went to my primary and she said just to finish it at Mercy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you are getting physical therapy for other issues other than your shoulder and your knee?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What other issues?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Well, since this one was torn, I overextended this one.  So now I have this one is torn.  I have fractures in my left hand, and I have fractures in my right hand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just for the record so we know what we are talking about later when we read this, you said you initially tore the left?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: The right in the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: And from not having the use of my right arm, I had to use my left arm, which I overextended my left arm and now this one is torn.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you were saying this one is overextended --
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: My left one, correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has any doctor told you that your left shoulder injury is related to your fall at Wal-Mart?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you had any --
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I'm sorry.  Dr. Miller did tell me that from having this one, this one was overextended, over something.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So Dr. Miller told you from having your right shoulder injured, you overdone your --
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Extended my left one, correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has Dr. Miller or any other doctor diagnosed you with any condition relating to your left shoulder?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I do have a torn rotator cuff.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that was Dr. Miller that told you that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: That was the orthopedic surgeon from UIC.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the month, year that you saw the UIC doctor?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I just seen him this year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know what month you saw him?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Probably about three months ago for the first time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So maybe around May?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Um-hum.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that a yes?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Yes.  I'm sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's okay.
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Have you had any pain or issue with your right knee?  We talked about the injury to your left knee.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Now, with my right knee, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has any doctor scheduled you for surgery of your left knee?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has any doctor told you that your left shoulder will need surgery?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  That was the orthopedic surgeon from UIC.  He wants to try the therapy first.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Are you on any prescription medications relating to your shoulder or knee pain now?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what are you on now?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I am on antidepressants.  I am on anxiety medication.  I am on pain medication.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I want to start with just the pain medication.  What pain medication are you on?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: The Hydrocodone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it the same frequency?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  I only -- it is five milligrams.  I only take it probably at night because that's when it hurts the most.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you say "it" hurts the most, are you referring to your knee, shoulder or both?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My shoulders.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Shoulders?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you still experiencing pain in your knee?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have to use anything to help you walk, like, a cane, a walker anything like that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You talked about taking antidepressants and anxiety medication.  Do you believe that is related to your accident at Wal-Mart?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how so?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: After I fell, it destroyed my life.  I lost my job.  I lost everything.  I had to go see a psychologist and a psychiatrist because everything was falling apart.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who referred you to the psychologist and psychiatrist?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My primary.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is the name of -- is it one person is a psychologist or psychiatrist, or is it two separate people?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Two separate people.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what are their names?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: The psychiatrist is Dr. K.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: K-A-Y?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Just K.  It' really long.  He is at Mercy, at the mental health center.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what about the psychologist?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I just -- I was just seeing Dr. K for kind of both, but he said that he is going to recommend me to somebody but there is a waiting list right now.  They are really backed up, so...
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often do you see Dr. K?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I see him every two to three months.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you start seeing Dr. K or how long after your accident, whichever is easier?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I have been seeing Dr. K probably for two years now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what medications has Dr. K prescribed for you?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I am on I think Lexapro, and there is another one that he has got me on.  I don't know what --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Another anxiety medication?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that a medication that you take daily --
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- or when you feel flare-ups?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  I take daily.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Off the record.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: (Discussion off the record.)
Back on the record.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: When is the last time you saw your primary doctor?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I see my primary once a month.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Once a month?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: And I just seen her last week, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And does she have you on any prescription medication right now?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I am on blood pressure, cholesterol, Lyrica. She has me on Lyrica.  I am not sure what else.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Lyrica for pain?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what pain is she prescribing the Lyrica for?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: All through here (indicating).
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that is your shoulder?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  Not only that, when Dr. Miller did my surgery, he was telling me that when he did it, there was going to be a twitch in my arm because he had to cut some muscle and do something.  Well, ever since he did this, I have this twitch now to where my neck twitches all the time.  It is kind of weird because I don't know if anybody can see it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you been telling your primary doctor about that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Oh, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The Norco that you were prescribed, who is -- that you are continuing to take, who is the keeper of that prescription?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Dr. Milenkovich.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So that prescription is now through her as well?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where do you frequently fill your prescriptions?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Walgreens and Crescent Pharmacy.  It is on 87th too.  It is right next to Dr. Rashan.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said you don't have an upcoming appointment with Dr. Miller?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We talked about this a little bit before, but I want to go back to it. What activities could you do before your fall at Wal-Mart that you can no longer do now?  We will start with just physical activities.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Okay.  I was able to lift my arms over my head.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Now, this is as far as I can go.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And for the record, your arms are just below parallel to --
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  I can't lift them any higher or else my muscles snap.  I can't fold clothes.  I can't do dishes. I can't wash my hair.  I can't make a bed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who does the household chores around the house now?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: My husband and my son and my daughter-in-law that just recently moved in.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you mentioned that you have trouble washing your hair.  Do you go somewhere now to have your hair washed or who helps you with that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  I just put my head over the sink and my husband does it.  After 36 years he better do something.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other activities around the house that you no longer can do?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: You know, I can't even play with my grandkids.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many grand children do you have?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Nine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is the range of ages with the grandkids?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Ten down to two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What types of activities did you do with your grandkids before your injury?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I used to be able to take them to the park, go on the swings, go down the slide, swing them around, pick them up.  I can't do any of that anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there any hobbies or things outside the house that you can't do now that you could do before your fall?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I can't go bowling.  That's for sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often did you used to go bowling?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: We used to bowl, like, once every two months.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have a location that you always went to the same one or where did you go?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  It just depended on where everyone wanted to go.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you in a league or anything like that?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.  It was just for fun.  It was just a bunch of adults trying to get out, get away from kids, grandkids.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other activities?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I can't swim.  I swam my whole life.  I was a lifeguard, you know, and I can't swim properly because of the pain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what pool did you used to go swimming at?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: McKinley Park.  I go on vacation; I can't swim.  I stand in the water.  I have a pool in my backyard for my grandkids.  All I can do is float.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other activities?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Not that I can think of.  The kids is the biggest one.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you sought out any temp agencies or anything like that to help you find jobs?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  I am on Medicare now.  I am on disability.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The disability payments that you are receiving now, are those related to your shoulder and knee injury?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Just the whole thing, the mental, just everything.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long have you been on disability?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I just started receiving it in the last two months.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Any other ways that the fall impacted your life that we have not touched on yet?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you been back to the Bedford Park store since your fall?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you been back to any Wal-Mart stores since your fall?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: Yes.  I love Wal-Mart.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What stores have you been to?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I go to the one in Countryside.  I go to the one on 103rd and Harlem.  I don't know what the address is.  And the one in Romeoville.  So I travel to go to these other Wal-Mart's.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At any of these other locations, have you talked to any of the employees there about your fall at Bedford Park?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Since your fall, have you had anymore communications with those two customers that were standing there?
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Those are all the questions that I have.
speaker: MS. HASKELL

text: I just have a couple of brief ones. EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: The grapes that you stepped in, when you observed them after the fall, they appeared to be trampled; is that correct?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you made the observation that you had come in contact with them with your foot; is that true?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Actually, it was all over my leg and my hand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right, but my question is, you had first come in contact with them with your foot; is that true?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then you had some on your pants leg; is that correct?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what you observed afterwards is they appeared to be -- you used the word trampled or smashed?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And we saw your fall on the video, correct?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Um-hum.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And it was your observation that they didn't appear to be just smashed from the time that you had fallen; is that true?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: True.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what gave you that impression in terms of your observations?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Because after I fell, when I got up, it wasn't freshly wet.  It was like they were stepped in, they were sticky, and it was just an icky feeling, you know, sticky and --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that stickiness ended up on your pants true?
speaker: MR. MALATESTA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's all I have.
